title: Jamie Dimon issues private credit warning: ‘When you see one cockroach, there are probably more’ - Fortune
summary:
But JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon also warned that if or when an economic downturn comes, investors should expect more companies that have taken on too much debt go the way of First Brands.
“And I probably shouldn’t say this, but when you see one cockroach, there are probably more.
CFO Jeremy Barnum said: “A lot of the private credit actors are large, very sophisticated, very good at credit underwriting.
And we don’t even know the standards [of] other banks’ underwriting to some of these entities.
“But I think we feel very, very good about our processes, our collateral, the structure of the book.”

title: Why Public/Private Market Funds’ Yields Are a Double-Edged Sword - Morningstar
summary:
That’s true for all funds, but especially for semiliquid funds.
Vehicles like interval funds, tender-offer funds, nontraded business development companies, and nontraded real estate investment trusts straddle private and public markets.
By borrowing money to buy more assets, funds can amplify gains and offer bigger distributions—especially in private credit, where double-digit yields have drawn crowds.
These vehicles, predominantly private credit funds, can borrow up to $2 for every $1 of investor capital, fueling eye-catching yields.
Beware the Fragility Leverage can make semiliquid funds look impressive until market stress exposes their cracks.

title: 3 Reasons to Care About Private Markets Even if You’re Not Investing in Them - Morningstar
summary:
Growth in private equity, venture capital, private debt, and other such funds has been truly astounding.
With abundant funding from private capital, companies can avoid the scrutiny, reporting, and regulation that come with publicly listing.
Private Capital Will Be Reshaping Investing for Years to Come In the PitchBook private capital data above, did you notice “dry powder” in the neighborhood of $4 trillion?
Private equity, venture capital, and private debt will continue to compete with public stock and bond markets for capital formation.
No matter your view on their relative merits, the impact of private markets’ growth can’t be ignored.

title: SoloTex Set to Bring Tokenized Stocks to U.S. Retail Traders With FINRA Green Light - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Stock tokenization spreads Tokenization of traditional assets has drawn growing interest from major financial firms and startups alike.
Tokenized stocks gained steam earlier this year as a roster of trading platforms and crypto exchanges rolled out tokenized equities including Gemini, Kraken, Bybit and Robinhood.
Meanwhile, synthetic stock tokens or exposure through special purpose vehicles (SPVs) that often don’t provide actual share ownership.
"Offering actual tokenized U.S. equities to the U.S. market has always been the holy grail," said Ashley Ebersole, legal advisor for SoloTex, in a statement.
Read more: Tokenized Stocks Aren’t Working (Yet) Recommended Stories

title: Dimon’s ‘Cockroach’ Fear Revives Threat of Cracks in Credit - Yahoo Finance
summary:
“I suspect when there’s a downturn you will see higher-than-normal downturn type of credit losses in certain categories,” he said.
While results sent shares of Citigroup and Wells Fargo higher, the downbeat notes and rising compensation costs trimmed prices at JPMorgan and Goldman.
Investors have been fleeing BDCs, seen as a proxy for the $1.7 trillion private-credit market, as they cut distributions available to shareholders.
Last month, the $75 billion non-traded Blackstone Private Credit Fund, the largest in the industry, said it was reducing its shareholder payouts.
Chief Financial Officer Jeremy Barnum and his Wells Fargo counterpart, Michael Santomassimo, reassured analysts that much of their exposures are to large, established private-credit players.

title: Eric Trump Confirms Plans to Tokenize Real Estate With World Liberty Financial - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Eric Trump, son of U.S. President Donald Trump and a co-founder of decentralized finance protocol World Liberty Financial (WLFI), said he is actively working on a real estate tokenization project tied to a building currently under development.
His comments followed Zach Witkoff, another WLFI co-founder, who floated plans to bring the Trump real estate portfolio onchain during a panel discussion at the Token2049 event in Singapore in early October.
Trump suggested in the interview on Wednesday that applying the tokenization model could open investment opportunities to his family’s global base of supporters.
While details remain scarce, he indicated the initiative would be integrated with World Liberty Financial and its U.S. dollar stablecoin USD1.
World Liberty Financial launched last year with a focus on merging crypto infrastructure with traditional financial services.
